metadata.title: Eco-friendly cellulose acetate green synthesized silver nano-composite as antibacterial packaging system for food safety

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Food Packaging and Shelf Life
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/fpsl
Eco-friendly cellulose acetate green synthesized silver nano-composite as antibacterial packaging system for food safety
Diaa A. Marreza, Ahmed E. Abdelhamidb, Osama M. Darweshc,⁎
a Food Toxicology and Contaminants Department, National Research Centre, Cairo, Egypt b Polymers & Pigments Department, National Research Centre, Cairo, Egypt c Agricultural Microbiology Department, National Research Centre, Cairo, Egypt
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Food packaging Silver nanoparticles Cellulose acetate Green synthesis Phenolic compounds
A B S T R A C T
The current study focused on preparation of environmentally safe nano-composite films from a mixture of cellulose acetate (CA) and nanosilver for using it as an antibacterial food packaging system against some foodborne pathogenic bacteria. Green synthesized silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) were prepared using different poly-phenolic; gallic and pyrogallic acid, quercetin and rutin and then characterized. UV–vis spectral was detected peaks in the area of AgNPs formation and High Resolution Transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) revealed that formation of nearly spherical AgNPs with an average size of 5 to 18 nm. All AgNPs had activity against the examined pathogenic bacteria reached to 10 folds more than the normal form of poly-phenolics. Also, minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) values were ranged between 16.7 and 46.7 μgml−1. The films of CAnanocomposite were prepared by phase inversion technique. The obtained films were characterized by FTIR, SEM, EDX techniques and their swelling properties were determined. Also, antibacterial activity of the film was assessed. CA-nanocomposite had high antibacterial activity against St. aureus, B. cereus, S. typhi, E. coli, K. pneumoniae and low activity against the two strains of Pseudomonase spp. All tested immersed films showed no toxic effect against larvae even used quercetin in the preparation (< 18% mortality). The released amount of Ag nanoparticles from different CA-nano-composite films was also less than the allowable limit. The current work conclude that the poly-phenolic CA -Ag nano-composite films had strong antibacterial activity with nontoxic effect, which increases the possibility of applying it as an active food packaging system.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Food spoilage and contamination cause many problems as loss of texture, color, nutritive rate and permits the pathogens growth, which decline the product quality and makes it non-edible (El-Naggar, Abouleid, El-Deeb, Abd-El-Kareem, & Elshahawy, 2016; Elshahawy, Saied Nehal, & Morsy, 2017; Malhotra, Keshwani, & Kharkwal, 2015). Food microbial contamination can be occurred during food handling, processing and packaging. To reduce that, several preservation methods were used to reduce food spoilage and increase food products shelf-life, like heating, drying, salting, freezing, fermentation and active antimicrobial packing system (Sung et al., 2013). Natural antimicrobial agents received cumulative attention due to their consumer attentiveness of natural food products and the growing concern of microbial resistance to conventional preservers (Schuenzel & Harrison, 2002). Most of foods preserving films were made from synthetic polymers like polyethylene (PE), polypropylene (PP), polyvinyl chloride (PVC) and
polyethylene terephthalate (PET) (Bruna, Galotto, Guarda, & Rodríguez, 2014). These polymeric materials are non-biodegradable and accumulate in the land causing numerous environmental problems (Varsha, Bajpai, & Navin, 2010). An alternative, ecofriendly green polymers based on natural and synthetic origins were developed for biodegradable packaging materials (Rodríguez, Galotto, Guarda, & Bruna, 2012). Cellulose acetate (CA) is an ecofriendly polymer derived from cellulose, capable of forming films at room temperatures, odorless, non-toxic, biodegradable, water insoluble, has minimum affinity for water vapors and considers promising material for using in food packaging system (Delaine, Regina, & Maryoris, 2015; Puls, Wilson, & Holter, 2011; Seyhun, Ahmet, & Sacide, 2009).
Antibacterial food packaging system is one of the innovative methods that has been introduced for improving the quality, safety and extend shelf-life of food products. It is a system capable to kill the foods contaminating bacteria (Malhotra et al., 2015). Antibacterial packaging film can be manufactured by direct combination and immobilization of
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.fpsl.2019.100302 Received 8 September 2018; Received in revised form 23 December 2018; Accepted 17 January 2019
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: darweshosama@yahoo.com (O.M. Darwesh).
Food Packaging and Shelf Life 20 (2019) 100302
2214-2894/ © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
T
antibacterial substances in packaging, surface modification or surface coating (Appendini & Hotchkiss, 2002; Scannell et al., 2000). Several compounds have been applied as antibacterial agents such as organic acids, enzymes, antibiotics, bacteriocins and metals (Dehnavi, Aroujalian, Raisi, & Fazel, 2013). Among these materials, silver nanoparticles which have widely used because it has high thermal stability and log-term activity toward various groups of bacteria, viruses and fungi (Baker, Pradhan, Pakstis, Pochan, & Shah, 2005). Regarding to the phenolic compounds, they are considered the most diverse groups of secondary metabolites found in edible plants. In nature, they are combined with plant growth and reproduction, provide resistance to pathogens and predators and protect crops from disease and pre-harvest seed germination (Ross & Kasum, 2002). Many different classes of polyphenols were discovered as flavonoids, tannins and lignin. Flavonoids are the most widely spread polyphenols that present in daily human consumed vegetables. Dietary flavonoids have concerned attention because they have a variety of useful bioactivity. It may play a significant role in the care of human health (Pandey & Rizvi, 2009). Flavonoids are free radical scavenger’s, metal chelators and powerful antioxidants; they inhibit peroxidation of lipid and exhibit several physiological activities including anti-inflammatory, anti-allergic, anticarcinogenic, anti-hypertensive, anti-arthritic and antimicrobial activities (Aly, Sabry, Shaheen, & Hathout, 2016). The results may possibly permit to formulate new products to be used as food preservatives or to be included in the human diet (Hintz, Matthews, & Di, 2015).
The current study aimed to prepare cellulose acetate film containing sliver nanoparticles for using as active food packaging system. For this purpose, (i) silver nanoparticles AgNPs were synthesized by reduction of silver ion using four phenolic compounds i.e, gallic and pyrogallic acid, rutin and quercetin, (ii) Incorporate the synthesized nanoparticles onto cellulose acetate films using casting technique, (iii) investigate the antibacterial properties of coated film against some food pathogenic bacterial strains and (iv) examine the toxicity and release of silver ion from the packing films.
2. Materials and methods
2.1. Materials
Cellulose acetate (40 wt% acetyl content, Avg. Mn: 37000, Aldrich). The phenolic compounds i.e, gallic acid, pyrogallic acid, rutin and quercetin were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, USA. Silver nitrate (AgNO3) and Acetone as locally product were obtained from El Naser Pharmaceutical Chemical Company, Egypt. Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, USA.
2.2. Preparation of silver nanoparticles (AgNPs)
Silver nanoparticles were synthesized using four phenolic compounds (gallic acid, pyrogallic acid, rutin and quercetin). A 50mg/ml of each compound freshly prepared in ddH2O was added separately to 0.01M silver nitrate solution at the ratio of 1:2 (v/v). The reaction mixture was incubated at room temperature (30 ̊C) until producing of nanoparticles. The obtained nanoparticle solution was purified by repeated centrifugation at 12,000 rpm for 20min followed by redispersion of the pellet in deionized water several times and dried by oven at 50 ̊C.
2.3. Preparation of cellulose acetate nanocomposite films
Cellulose acetate films (CA) were prepared using solution casting method (Bruna et al., 2014). CA was dissolved in acetone with weight percent (10% w/v) under stirring for 2 h till complete dissolution to obtain control CA. Nano-silver synthesised by phenolic compounds (gallic acid, pyrogallic acid, rutin and quercetin) (0.05% w/w respect to CA) was dispersed in acetone using ultrasonic water bath for about 1 h
prior to the addition of cellulose acetate to obtain CA-G, CA-P, CA-R, CA-Q respectively. After complete dissolution it was ultrasonicated for about half an hour. The casting solution was poured onto a glass plate at room temperature then drawn out into films with film applicator set at a thickness of 400 μm. The casted films were allowed for solvent evaporation at ambient conditions till complete drying, removed and stored in packages of polyethylene (PE) for further analysis.
2.4. Characterization of AgNPs
2.4.1. UV–vis spectral analysis Synthesis of AgNPs was monitored using a Jenway UV/VIS scanning spectrophotometer (Jenway UV/Visible- 2605 spectrophotometer, England). The UV–vis spectra were recorded between 200–500 nm.
2.4.2. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) The morphology and size of the reductive AgNPs were examined by High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM) JEOL (JEM-2100 TEM). The samples were prepared by placing few drops of the nanoparticles suspension on carbon coated copper gride, followed by allowing the solvent to evaporate slowly before recording the TEM image.
2.4.3. Scanning electron microscopy and metals analysis for the produced films
The surface morphology of the examined sample was imaged with scanning electron microscope (SEM) (QUANTA FEG 250 ESEM) attached with energy dispersive x-ray Analyses, with accelerating voltage 30 K for determination of elements and the distribution of silver particles in the membrane matrix.
2.4.4. FTIR spectroscopy analysis The Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectroscopic was recorded with an FTIR spectrophotometer (Shimadzu 8400, Japan). The scans recorded were the average of 100 scans and the selected spectral range between 400 and 4000 cm−1.
2.5. Swelling behavior of cellulose acetate nanocomposite films
The water content (WC) of the nano-composite films was obtained by immersion 1.5× 1.5 cm for 3 samples of each film in distilled water for 24 h at room temperature and calculated using the following equation:

sections.heading: WC = (W1−W0 / W1) × 100
sections.text:
Where W1 and W0 are the weight of swelled and dried samples, respectively
The degree of swelling (Sw) for the nano-composite was calculated using the following equation:
Sw = (W1−W0 / W0)
2.6. Silver nanoparticles release
To determine the releasing of silver nanoparticles from the cellulose acetate nanocomposite films, a piece of each film (10 x 10 cm) was immersed in 100ml of distilled water at room temperature. After certain time; 24, 48, 72 h, the solution was taken to evaluate the silver content using atomic absorption spectroscopy (Agilent Technologies 200 Series AA, wavelength for silver 328.1 nm).
2.7. Toxicity evaluation of CA nanocomposite films using brine shrimp lethal assay
Brine shrimp eggs (Artemia salina leach) were supplied by Avocet
Artemin Inc., Utah, USA. Artemia salina cysts of 1 g were aerated in 1 l capacity of glass jar containing 3.6% of sea water (36 g sea salt in liter). The jar was aerated constantly for 48 h at room temperature. After hatching, active free-floating nauplii was collected from bright illumination and were used for the bioassay. Larvae were used within 24 h of hatching. Pieces of cellulose acetate film and cellulose acetate PC-Ag nanocomposite films (10 x 10 cm2) were immersed in 100ml of distilled water at room temperature. After certain 24, 48, 72 h, the solution was taken to evaluate the toxic effect (Emam, Darwesh, & Abdelhameed, 2018; Meyer et al., 1982). The number of dead shrimps that was placed in 5 vials (10 shrimps/vial) was counted and percent mortality was calculated.
2.8. Antibacterial assay
2.8.1. Tested microorganisms Seven species of foodborne pathogenic bacteria i.e. two Gram-positive bacteria: Bacillus cereus EMCC 1080, Staphylococcus aureus ATCC 13,565 and five Gram-negative bacteria: Salmonella typhi ATCC 25566, Escherichia coli 0157 H7 ATCC 51659, Pseudomonas aeruginosa NRRL B272, Pseudomonas fluorescens F10 and Klebsiella pneumoniae LMD 7726 were used in this study to evaluate the antibacterial activity of phenolic compounds, AgNPs and CA modified films (Kheiralla, Hewedy, Mohammed, & Darwesh, 2016; Khalil et al., 2017).
2.8.2. Disc diffusion method From the 24 h incubated nutrient agar slant of each bacterial species, a full loop of the tested microorganism was inoculated in a tube containing 5ml of tryptic soy broth. The broth culture was incubated at 35 ̊C for 2–6 h until it achieves the turbidity of 0.5 McFarland BaSO4 standard. The bioactivity of phenolic compounds (PC) and AgNPs were examined against all the tested bacterial species using disc diffusion method of Kirby-Bauer technique (Bauer, Kirby, Sheriss, & Turck, 1966). Using cotton swabs, nutrient agar plates were uniformly inoculated with tryptic soy broth of bacterial cultures. A concentration of 10 and 1mgml−1 for each PC and AgNPs, respectively was prepared by dissolving in 1ml of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). Sterilized discs (6 mm) from Whatman No. 1 filter paper were loaded by the tested samples and dried completely under sterile conditions. The discs were placed on the seeded plates by sterile forceps. DMSO and tetracycline (1mgml−1) were represented the negative and positive control, respectively. Also, the antimicrobial activity of the cellulose acetate film and the cellulose acetate silver nanocomposite films were determined using the disc diffusion method. The nanocomposite films (1× 1 cm) were firstly sterilized by UV light for 30min then placed on the plate surfaces. Inoculated plates were incubated at 37 ̊C for 24 h, and then the inhibition zones were measured and expressed as the diameter of clear zone including the diameter of the paper disc and films.
2.8.3. Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) The determination of MIC was conducted using tube dilution method (Irith, Kai, & Robert, 2008). A 24 h culture of the tested
bacterial strains was diluted in 10ml of tryptic soy broth (TSB) with reference to the 0.5 McFarland standard to achieve inocula of 108 cfu ml−1. Culture tube containing nine different concentrations of each phenolic compound (2.0, 1.75, 1.5, 1.25, 1.0, 0.75, 0.5, 0.25, 0.1mg ml−1) and nine different concentrations of each produced AgNPs (100, 75, 60, 50, 40, 35, 30, 20, 10 μg ml−1) in DMSO were prepared. Each tube was inoculated with 100 μl of bacterial cell suspension and incubated at 37 ̊C for 24 h. The growth of the inoculum in broth is indicated by turbidity of the broth and the lowest concentration which inhibited the growth of the test organism was taken as the MIC (Ali, Mohamed, Sameeh, Darwesh, & Abd El-Razik, 2016; Sultan, Ali, Darwesh, Embaby, & Marrez, 2016).

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
The current study concentrated on enhancement of antibacterial activity of packaging system using cellulose acetate films enriched by green synthesized AgNPs as active packaging system for increasing the food safety and extends shelf-life of food materials.
3.1. Antibacterial activity of the phenolic compounds
The antibacterial activity of gallic and pyrogallic acid, rutin and quercetin against 7 pathogenic bacterial strains were illustrated in Table 1. The results showed that gallic acid possess high antibacterial activity toward B. cereus, E. coli and S. typhi with inhibition zones, 18.5, 21.8 and 20.5 mm, respectively. Whereas, pyrogallic acid showed high antibacterial activity against St. aureus, P. aeruginosa, P. fluorescens and K. pneumoniae with zone of inhibition; 22.5, 15.5, 15.5 and 16.8 mm, respectively. Also, the lowest MIC value, 0.82mgml−1, was recorded by pyrogallic acid and quercetin against St. aureus and S. typhi, while high MIC, 1.42mgml−1, was observed against P. fluorescens by gallic acid. Several studies observed the activity of phenolic compounds towards food borne pathogenic bacteria. In a study achieved by Singh, Govindarajan, Rawat, and Khare (2008), rutin as flavonoid was exhibited high activity against St. aureus, B. cereus, E. coli, P. aeruginosa, S. typhimurium and K. pneumoniae with MIC values< 0.15mgml−1. Also, Fattouch et al. (2007) indicated that quercetin and rutin showed a high activity against St. aureus and P. aeruginosa. Jayaraman, Sakharkar, Lim, Tang, and Sakharkar (2010) observed a MIC of 2000 μg ml−1 with gallic acid against five strains of P. aeruginosa. While, Borges, Ferreira, Saavedra, and Simões (2013) reported that gallic acid had activity against St. aureus, E. coli and P. aeruginosa with MIC values ranged between 500–1750 μg ml−1. Marrez et al. (2017) found that the phenolic profile of A. wilkesiana ethyl acetate extract contains gallic acid had antibacterial activity against St. aureus, B. cereus, E. coli, P. aeruginosa, S. typhi and K. pneumoniae. Xie, Jing, Aiping, and Liangliang (2017) reported that the polyphenols quercetin, rutin, gallic and pyrogallic acid showed significant antibacterial activities, especially the pyrogallic acid against St. aureus, E. coli and S. typhimurium with MIC ranged between 0.5 and 2.5mmol/L. These MIC values were in accordance with the range of those found in the present study.
3.2. Preparation and characterization of silver nanoparticles
Nanoparticles of silver were prepared using polyphenolic compounds; gallic and pyrogallic acid, quercetin and rutin as a reducing agents. The nanoparticles were produced after 24 h of incubation with gallic acid, rutin and quercetin reagents, while the silver nano-size was produced after 15min with pyrogallic acid reagent. These likely depend on the reducing activity of the used components (Mittal, Bhaumik, Kumar, & Banerjee, 2014). Changing in solution mixtures colour is considered the first indicator and easily procedure for detection of nano-metal synthesis. After reduction of metals, the colour of solution will be turned to another one resulting of nanoparticles formation. This colour was observed visually (Park, Cha, Cho, & Park, 2016). After gradually increasing of colour as observed by visual examination, the formation of silver nanoparticles was detected by scanning the produced component on UV/Vis spectrophotometer. The produced peaks were illustrated in Fig. 1. The maximum peak of silver nano-size formation was detected at 400 nm when using quercetin and rutin as reducing agent, while the maximum peak was observed at 385 and 395 nm with pyrogallic and gallic acid, respectively. In this trend, some articles were reported the peak of green synthesized AgNPs at absorption range of 380:420 nm (El-Naggar, Abdelwahed, & Darwesh, 2014; Elshahawy, Abouelnasr, Lashin, & Darwesh, 2018).
3.3. HRTEM characterization of silver nanoparticles
Visualized nanoparticle formation should be confirmed using microscopic techniques such as TEM, AFM and SEM. Microscopic visualization leads information about the shape, size, 2 and/or 3-dimensional
nano-topography, related to materials aggregation/agglomeration (Park et al., 2016). The synthesis of AgNPs by the four reducers was characterized by HRTEM and the resulting pictures were presented in Fig. 1. The results showed producing silver particles at nano-scale has different sizes. When using gallic acid and rutin as reducers, the size of silver nanoparticles was ranged between 13–18 nm. However, the size was ranged between 5–10 nm when pyrogallic acid and quercetin used as reducers. The shape of all produced silver nano-size was nearly spherical.
3.4. Antibacterial activity of AgNPs produced by the phenolic compounds
The results of antibacterial activity of gallic and pyrogallic acid, rutin and quercetin prepared silver nanoparticles against 7 strains of foodborne pathogenic bacteria were summarized in Table 2. Maximum inhibition zone, 28.3 mm, was observed against E. coli by pyrogallic AgNPs followed by gallic AgNPs which being 26.8 mm against S. typhi. Gallic AgNPs exhibited high antibacterial activity against St. aureus, B. cereus, S. typhi and P. aeruginosa with inhibition zones, 26.7, 21.7, 26.8 and 20.5 mm, respectively. Pyrogallic AgNPs showed high activity against E. coli and P. fluorescens, while rutin AgNPs had high activity against K. pneumoniae with zone of inhibition, 21.7mm. Generally, all tested phenolic compounds produced AgNPs had antibacterial activity 10 fold more than the applied phenolic compounds. The MIC values of phenolic compounds AgNPs against all the examined pathogenic bacteria were ranged from 16.7 to 46.7 μg ml−1 (Table 2). The highest MIC value was recorded against E. coli by quercetin AgNPs and the lowest one was noted against P. fluorescens by rutin AgNPs. In this trend Li, Liu, Yuan, Liu, and Niu (2015) found that the gallic acid AgNPs
demonstrated antibacterial activity against E. coli and S. aureus with MIC of 6 and 30 μg ml-1, respectively. Sun et al. (2017) reported that quercetin AgNPs showed highly antibacterial activity against drug-resistant E. coli and S. aureus. Also, Jain and Mehata (2017) indicated that quercetin AgNPs had activity against E. coli with MIC value of 50 μg ml1. Marrez et al. (2017) revealed that the phenolic extract of A. wilkesiana seeds AgNPs contains gallic acid had antibacterial activity against St. aureus, B. cereus, P. aeruginosa, E. coli, S. typhi and K. pneumonia with MIC value ranged between 0.2 to 0.37mgml−1. Ali et al. (2015) indicated that green synthesized AgNPs by Eucalyptus globulus leaf extract containing gallic acid, rutin and quercetin as major components had activity against St. aureus, P. aeruginosa and E. coli.
3.5. FTIR of cellulose acetate (CA) and CA containing AgNPs films
The FTIR spectra of the untreated and treated CA samples were analysed and the produced peaks shown in Suppl. (1). In the CA spectrum, characteristic absorption bands could be found at 3450 cm−1 characteristic to cellulosic eOH stretching, asymmetric and symmetric CeH stretching at 2940 and 2880 cm−1 corresponding to CH3 and CeH, respectively. The C]O of carbonyl of acetate group have a stretching band at 1730 cm−1, carboxylate CeO stretch at 1220 cm−1, asymmetric stretching of the CeOeC bridge at 1160 cm−1, and stretching of pyranose ring CeOeC at 1028 cm−1 (Kamal, AbdElrahim, & Lotfy, 2014). The very low concentration of AgNPs reduced with phenolic compounds make their peaks not clearly detectable in the IR spectra. However there is some characteristic peaks at 1500 and 1628 cm−1 corresponding to] C]C aromatic ring of phenolic compounds. The carbonyl group band slightly shifted from 1728 cm−1 for the blank film to 1755, 1758, 1756 and 1759 cm−1 for CAeP, CAeR, CAeQ and CAeG respectively representing stabilization of AgNPs by carbonyl bands from cellulose acetate films. The peak at 3450 cm−1 for composite samples containing nanoparticle are broaden due to the presence of hydroxyl groups of phenolic compounds and formation of hydrogen bonding.
3.6. Scanning Electron microscope (SEM) and EDX
The presence and distribution of AgNPs in the composite films were more clearly shown by EDX mapping for two nano-composite films CAG and CA-R (Fig. 2). The two selected nanocomposites represents the two category (gallic and pyrogallic are consider one category as their structure resembles each other with little difference, quercetin and rutin consider one category). The EDX spectrum of AgNPs–in CA-G membrane showed 53.32 wt% for C, 46.63 wt% for O and 0.06 wt% for Ag (Fig. 2a), and for CA-R showed 52.93 wt% for C, 47 wt% for O and 0.07 wt% for Ag. These results indicate that found low concentrations of AgNPs in the membrane matrix. The distribution of nanoparticles in the membrane was clearly seen in the elemental mapping for the silver showing uniform dispersion and distribution density with no large aggregation in the film samples. The obtained results indicate the effective of synthesized method using the tested phenolic compounds for capping nano-silver and stable immobilization in cellulose acetate films.
3.7. Swelling properties of CA nanocomposite films
From Table 3, it can be commented that the blank cellulose acetate has the lower swelling and lower water content than the nano-composite films containing AgNPs with phenolic compounds. The higher water content for nano-composite films may be due to the hydrophilic character of the phenolic compounds resulted from hydroxyl groups. All films have low degree of swelling ranged from 0.28 to 0.65 and low water content that range from 25 to 36%. These results indicates that the low hydrophilicity of CA compared with more hydrophilic crosslinking polyvinyl alcohol reported by Musetti et al. (2014) with water content ranged from 92 to 94.8% and swelling from 12.5 to 18.4. The
obtained data point to CA films considers good applicant for using in the food packaging system.
3.8. Antibacterial activity of cellulose acetate-AgNPs films
Antibacterial activity of the polyphenolic silver coated CA nanocomposite films against two Gram-positive and five Gram-negative species of foodborne pathogens were evaluated by agar diffusion and results are represented in Table 4 and Suppl. (2). Gallic acid nanocomposite showed the maximum inhibition zone against St. aureus, E. coli and P. aeruginosa (25.5, 20.7, 11.5mm, respectively) than other polyphenolics nano-composite films. Also, quercetin nano-composite had elevated activity against B. cereus and S. typhi with inhibition zone 18.2 and 21.2 mm, respectively. While, pyrogallic CA nano-composite film exhibited high inhibition zones 11.7 and 20.5mm against P. fluorescens and K. pneumoniae, respectively. The lowest effect of tested films was recorded against P. aeruginosa and P. fluorescens.
Many authors worked in this field to establish a new system of food packaging based on organic polymers entrapping by green synthesis nano-bioactive agents. Son, Youk, and Park (2006) reported that CA nanofibers containing AgNPs had powerful activity against E. coli, P. aeruginosa, St. aureus and K. pneumonia. Moura, Mattoso, and Zucolotto (2012) found that hydroxypropyl methyl cellulose-AgNPs nano-composite films exhibited antibacterial activity against St. aureus and E. coli. Sun, Wang, Kadouh, and Zhou (2014) revealed that the adding of gallic acid on chitosan films with different concentration increased the antibacterial activity of the chitosan films against S. typhimurium, Listeria innocua and B. subtilis. Necula et al. (2010) reported that cellulose acetate and CA phthalate films containing AgNPs had more intense inhibition against E. coli and St. aureus when compared with the results of cellulose acetate and cellulose acetate phthalate films. Also, Andrade et al. (2015) indicated that cellulose acetate membrane containing AgNPs showed antibacterial activity against E. coli and S. aureus. Xu et al. (2006) found that E. coli was more sensitive to CA-AgNPs film than S. aureus and indicated that the antibacterial activity of CA-AgNPs depends not only on the chemical structure of CA-AgNPs but also on the bacterial cell membrane structure.
3.9. Toxicity effect of cellulose acetate PC-AgNPs films in brine shrimp
In order to achieve a safe treatment with cellulose acetate PCAgNPs, the toxicity of each immersed film was biologically assays using brine shrimp Artemia salina (Data not presented). In CA film as a control the mean percentage of survival after 24 h of exposure was 97.5%. The largest decrease in survival 82.5% was recorded with quercetin Ag nanocomposite film after 72 h of immersed in distilled water. Most toxicity studies use brine shrimp bioassay determines the toxicity after 24 h of exposure to the tested samples. Brine shrimp assay is an excellent predictive tool for the toxic potential of natural extracts in humans (Hamidi, Tаtјаnа, & Panovska, 2014). Darwesh, Sultan, Seif, and Marrez (2018) applied the brine shrimp bioassay to evaluate the toxicity of chitosan nano-form and recommended that this technique was the first bioassay technique for toxicity examination. Naidu, Ismail, and Sasidharan (2014) indicated that the extracts are not-toxic when LC50 values for the brine shrimp were above 1000 μg ml−1. KowalskaGóralska, Lawa, and Senze (2011) reported that brine shrimp specimens exposed by 6 h in silver solution at a concentration of 10mg L−1 showed average survivability near to 93%. So, all results must be confirmed by the silver ion release.
3.10. Silver nanoparticles release
Quantities of silver nanoparticles release in distilled water from polyphenolics cellulose acetate nano-composite films after 24, 48 and 72 h of storage were performed in this study (Data not shown). The quantity of Ag nanoparticles migration from CA nanocomposite films
into water after 72 h was not detectable in both gallic and pyrogallic CA nanocomposite films and less than its allowable concentration (10 ppm) in both rutin and quercetin CA nanocomposite films, 0.05 and 0.027 ppm, respectively. AgNPs and its nano-composites are one of the most widely used nanomaterials, as antimicrobials, in the food industry.
Several silver-containing substances have been approved by the U.S. FDA for use as food contact materials for the purpose of disinfection (U.S. FDA, 2015). Several reports recorded that silver nanocomposite are safe for food packaging, with no detectable or insignificant levels of silver ion that are release from impregnated containers into food sample (Addo Ntim, Thomas, Begley, & Noonan, 2015; Metak, Nabhani, & Connolly, 2015). Dehnavi et al. (2013) found that by increasing the immersion time of low density polyethylene silver nanocomposite in aqueous solution release sliver nanoparticles from coated films were increased. The amounts of silver ions released from the CA films are lower than the permissible limits (Commission Regulation (EU) (2011)).

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
The antibacterial food packaging films were prepared by
incorporation polyphenolics green synthesized AgNPs into CA films as environmental safe agent. CA nanocomposite had powerful antibacterial activity against several foodborne bacterial pathogens. Silver ion release profile from CA nanocomposites films were depended on Ag reductive compound and all nanocomposites films were less than the permissible limits. This study demonstrates the possibility using of CAAg nanocomposite as active food packaging materials.

sections.text: Supplementary material related to this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.fpsl.2019.100302.

metadata.abstractText: The current study focused on preparation of environmentally safe nano-composite films from a mixture of cellulose acetate (CA) and nanosilver for using it as an antibacterial food packaging system against some foodborne pathogenic bacteria. Green synthesized silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) were prepared using different poly-phenolic; gallic and pyrogallic acid, quercetin and rutin and then characterized. UV–vis spectral was detected peaks in the area of AgNPs formation and High Resolution Transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) revealed that formation of nearly spherical AgNPs with an average size of 5 to 18 nm. All AgNPs had activity against the examined pathogenic bacteria reached to 10 folds more than the normal form of poly-phenolics. Also, minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) values were ranged between 16.7 and 46.7 μgml. The films of CAnanocomposite were prepared by phase inversion technique. The obtained films were characterized by FTIR, SEM, EDX techniques and their swelling properties were determined. Also, antibacterial activity of the film was assessed. CA-nanocomposite had high antibacterial activity against St. aureus, B. cereus, S. typhi, E. coli, K. pneumoniae and low activity against the two strains of Pseudomonase spp. All tested immersed films showed no toxic effect against larvae even used quercetin in the preparation (< 18% mortality). The released amount of Ag nanoparticles from different CA-nano-composite films was also less than the allowable limit. The current work conclude that the poly-phenolic CA -Ag nano-composite films had strong antibacterial activity with nontoxic effect, which increases the possibility of applying it as an active food packaging system.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
